Materials Science and Catalysis Division Poornaprajna Institute of Scientific Research (PPISR) Bidalur post Devanahalli Bengaluru 562164 India The bimetallic oxide dispersed on silanol rich SBA-15-OH was designed for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from epoxides and CO2. The SBA-15-OH was synthesized via desilication and active metals were loaded by sol-gel method. Pure Sn-Ni oxide with a low surface area and lesser activity was modified by dispersing it on a high surface area SBA-15-OH. The different characterization techniques such as XRD, N2-sorption, CO2 and NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, SEM-EDX, TEM and XPS confirmed that the surface silanol group acts as anchoring site for the enhanced metal oxide-support interaction. Supported Sn-Ni oxide exhibited 16-fold better activity than pure Sn-Ni oxide, due to improved dispersion, which enhances the accessibility of reactants to the catalytic sites. Under the optimized reaction conditions 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH gave 92.9 % styrene oxide conversion and 84.3 % selectivity for styrene carbonate. The catalyst is recyclable and the flexibility of the catalyst is tested for different epoxides with CO2. Graphical abstract The Sn-Ni oxide dispersed on silanol rich SBA-15-OH catalyst was designed for the synthesis of cyclic carbonate from CO2 and epoxides. The surface silanol group acts as anchoring sites for better metal oxide–support interaction, which resulted into enhanced catalytic activity compared to pure Sn-Ni oxide by 15 fold. Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 valorization Heterogeneous catalysis Epoxide Cyclic carbonate Supported bimetallic oxide Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The rise in CO2 concentration in the atmosphere from pre-industrial era to present day due to increasing population and industrialization has badly impacted the environment [1]. It is well known that CO2 is a greenhouse gas that causes global warming and ocean acidification. Apart from that, CO2 is a non-toxic, abundant and non-flammable C1 feedstock [2]. Therefore, many scientific communities are developing inventive methods to utilize CO2 and convert it into value-added chemicals. Till today, many processes have been developed to transform CO2 into value-added chemicals such as methanol, formic acid, dimethyl ether, dimethyl carbonate, cyclic carbonate, cyclic and substituted urea [3–7]. Synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides is 100 % atom-economical, cost effective and has many industrial applications such as electrolytes in lithium ion batteries, fuel additives, intermediates for pharmaceutical compounds, lubricants and polymer industries [8]. Several catalyst systems have been studied for the synthesis of styrene carbonate (SC) from CO2 and styrene oxide (SO) by knowing its potential for commercial applications due to its properties such as high dielectric constant, biocompatibility, nontoxicity, high boiling point, dipole moment, stereo selectivity etc. The synthesis of organic carbonates from CO2 is still challenging because CO2 is a thermodynamically stable molecule and to activate it under mild condition is very difficult without its activation by a catalyst. An extensive amount of research has been done on exploring different types of homogenous and heterogeneous catalysts for CO2 conversion to cyclic carbonates [9]. Various homogeneous catalysts such as phosphorus ylide [10–13], porphyrin complex [14–19], salen complexes [20–24], amino-phenolate complexes [25,26], ionic liquids [27–31], and metal complexes [32–34] have been studied under mild reaction parameters with high catalytic activity. Both homogenous and heterogeneous catalysts have their own benefits and drawbacks, yet homogenous catalysts typically give higher catalytic activity than its counterpart. Still, heterogeneous catalysts are desirable due to easy separation from reaction mixture, easy handling, higher stability, regeneration and recyclability of the catalyst [35,36]. In this perspective, many heterogeneous catalysts are reported such as modified polymers [28,37–39], metal-organic frameworks [40–50], graphene oxide [51–54], functionalized silica [55–58], and graphitic carbon nitrides [59–63]. Though they show good catalytic activity for epoxide and CO2 reaction, their synthesis procedure is tedious and is not cost-effective. Moreover, these materials have low thermal and chemical stability, which would be difficult for catalyst regeneration. The grafted graphene oxides and supported ionic liquids are effective only in the presence of halide ions which do not satisfy the green chemistry principles. Supported quaternary ammonium salts and amine functionalized silica showed good activity for carbonylation of epoxides by CO2. However, these catalysts have inherent leaching issues. Many of these heterogeneous catalysts have addressed the limitations of homogenous catalyst systems but still there is a room for improvement for these heterogeneous catalysts in terms of achieving high activity under mild reaction conditions and good recyclability without any leaching issues. Many mono and mixed metal oxides are reported for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates by carbonylation of epoxides, such as MgO [64], La-Zr oxide [65], Mg-Al oxide [66] and Nb2O5 [67]. However, one or the other parameters like harsh reaction conditions or the usage of tetrabutylammonium bromide as homogenous co-catalyst or supercritical CO2 (high pressure) helped these oxide catalysts to get better yields [68,69]. Recently, our group reported Sn-Ni oxide catalyst for the synthesis of cyclic carbonate from epoxide and CO2 with a detailed study on propylene carbonate synthesis [70]. However, this metal oxide gave low turnover number for epoxide conversion due to low surface area and low availability of active sites on the surface. This is an inherent problem with most of the mixed metal oxides as major quantity of the catalytic active sites present in the bulk inside the big clusters of oxides. Hence, there is a need to develop a method to disperse the metal oxides on the high surface area support with most of the metal species accessible to the reactants. The dispersion of bulk oxides on the high surface area support gives stability and better exposure to the active sites as well as it brings out strong metal support interaction [71] that might enhance the catalytic activity. Previously, SBA-15 has been functionalized with various amine groups for cyclic carbonate synthesis from epoxide and CO2 and in another work, SBA-15 has been used along with homogeneous quaternary ammonium salt as co-catalyst for the same reaction [72]. In this study, SBA-15 has been used as support for metal oxides due to its promising properties such as high surface area, high pore wall thickness, large pore size and pore volume, suitable for the dispersion of metal oxide. The preparation of supported metal oxide catalyst needs a conducive interaction of the support with metal oxide to achieve better dispersion, higher stability and recyclability of the catalyst. SBA-15 is an ordered mesoporous silicate material with uniform hexagonal pore structure. Silicates are irreducible oxides which lack the strong metal support interaction property leading to the formation of weaker secondary bonds with metal oxide species [73]. However, many in-situ and post-modification methods enable the proper dispersion and interaction with metal species. The well-known desilication process is mainly used to design hierarchical zeolite catalysts by treatment with alkaline solution at pH 10-11 [74]. Similarly, the defect sites can also be generated in silicate framework using the desilication technique to create a silanol rich surface. This embraces a different coordination environment compared to a perfect silica framework. These surface-defect sites act as anchoring sites and promote the silica-metal oxide interaction. We attempted to develop a new method for uniform dispersion of metal oxides on SBA-15 by creating more anchoring sites on the support by a simple alkali treatment for CO2 transformation. The effectiveness of desilication process to achieve silanol rich surface and its reflectance on achieving better metal oxide dispersion has been studied. The interaction between metal oxide and silanol-rich SBA-15 support is investigated using different characterization techniques, and its structure activity relationship is investigated. Further, the effect of reaction conditions, leaching, recyclability and substrate scope of different epoxides were also studied in detail. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Styrene oxide, propylene oxide, cyclohexene oxide, 1,2-epoxy-3-phenoxypropane and poly(ethylene glycol)-block-poly(propylene glycol)-block-poly(ethylene glycol) with average molecular weight, 5800 (hereafter triblock P123), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) were procured from Sigma Aldrich. Nickel(II)nitrate hexahydrate, citric acid anhydrous, N,N-dimethylformamide (hereafter DMF), hydrochloric acid (35 %) and sodium hydroxide pellets were purchased from Merck, India. Stannic chloride hydrate and epichlorohydrin were purchased from Loba Chemie Pvt. Ltd. India. All the chemicals procured were used as it is without further modification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of SBA-15 The detailed procedure for mesoporous silica SBA-15 synthesis was first reported by GD Stucky and coworkers [75]. The SBA-15 was prepared using triblock P123 copolymer as a structure directing agent. In a typical procedure, 4 g triblock P123 copolymer was dissolved in 30 ml of water and 120 g of 2 M HCl solution was added under stirring. Then, 8 g of TEOS was added as a silica source to the above homogenous solution. This mixture was constantly stirred for 24 h at 40 °C. The obtained white gel was subjected for hydrothermal treatment in a polypropylene bottle at 100 °C for 48 h. The solid product was filtered and washed with distilled water followed by drying in air at room temperature. Finally, the material was calcined at 550 °C for 24 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min to remove the template and obtain a white powder SBA-15. 2.2.2 Preparation of silanol rich SBA-15 The calcined SBA-15 was post-synthetically modified by alkali treatment with different concentrations of diluted aq. NaOH solution. Typically, 1 g of calcined SBA-15 was added to 10 ml of x M aq. NaOH solution and the mixture was stirred for 1 h at 80 °C. Then, obtained material was filtered, washed with distilled water till the pH of the filtrate was 7 and dried in a hot air oven for 12 h at 110 °C to obtain white powder SBA-15-OH. The resultant material was labeled as SBA-15-OH-z M, where z refers to concentration of NaOH solution. If the z M concentration is not mentioned in the sample name, it is understood as 0.1 M aq. NaOH-treated sample. 2.2.3 Preparation of xSnyNi/SBA-15-OH-z M The SBA-15-OH supported Sn-Ni oxide catalyst was synthesized by sol-gel method using citric acid as a complexing agent. In a typical synthesis, SnCl4·5H2O and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O were taken as Sn and Ni precursors. The required amount of SnCl4·5H2O, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and citric acid with citric acid/ metal salts ratio of 1.2, were dissolved in 30 ml water and stirred for 1 h at room temperature. Then, 1 g of SBA-15-OH-z M was added to the above solution under constant stirring. This mixture was stirred for 2 h at room temperature followed by ultra-sonication for 2 h and then heated at 80 °C to evaporate the solvent. The obtained solid sample was dried at 110 °C for 5 h and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h @ 5 °C/min in static air. The formed catalyst contains Sn-Ni oxide dispersed on SBA-15-OH support which is denoted as xSnyNi/SBA-15-OH-z M, where, x and y are wt.% of Sn and Ni, respectively taken during the preparation. Similarly, different catalysts like Sn-Ni oxide on SBA-15 (without alkali treatment), Ni-oxide on SBA-15-OH, and Sn-oxide on SBA-15-OH were synthesized using the above procedure and denoted as xSnyNi/SBA-15, xSn/SBA-15-OH, yNi/SBA-15-OH, respectively. The pure form of Sn-Ni oxide (2:1) without support was prepared as per our previous report [70]. 2.3 Catalyst characterization A wide-angle powder X-ray diffraction (WAXRD) patterns of the catalysts were recorded with Bruker D2-phaser with CuKα radiation (λ=1.5418 Å) and high resolution Lynxeye detector. The catalysts were scanned with 2θ value from 5 to 90ₒ with 0.02° per step at a rate of 0.3 s/step. The small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) patterns were obtained with 2θ values between 0.5 and 10ₒ using Rigaku Smartlab X-ray diffractometer with CuKα radiation (λ=1.5418 Å) and SC-70 detector. The N2-sorption isotherms were obtained using Belsorp mini-II instrument (Bel, Japan) at liquid nitrogen temperature (77 K) after degassing the catalysts at 250 ₒC for 2 h. The specific surface area and pore volume were determined using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation and BJH plot was used to determine the pore size of the samples. The acidity and basicity of the samples were determined by Temperature Programmed-Desorption (TPD) using NH3 and CO2 gases as probe molecules, respectively with Belcat-II instrument (BEL, Japan). In a typical procedure, samples were preheated at 500 °C under argon flow for 1 h in quartz-tube reactor prior to the analysis. The sample was cooled down to 50 °C and 10 % of NH3 in He (or 10 % CO2 in He) was passed through the catalyst for 30 min. The physisorbed NH3 (or CO2) was purged out by passing He gas for 15 min. The NH3 (or CO2) desorption was recorded with a temperature ranging from 50 to 600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 under He flow. H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) studies were conducted on Belcat-II instrument (BEL, Japan) to analyze the reducibility of the materials and to understand the metal-support interaction. The samples were loaded in quartz tube reactor and preheated at 500 °C under Ar flow prior to the analysis and cooled down to 50 °C. Then, the gas was changed to 10 % H2 in Ar flow and temperature increased from 50 °C to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The thermal stability of the catalysts was analyzed by thermal analysis system (Perkin Elmer STA 6000). The experiments were carried out under air atmosphere from 30 to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 and flow rate of 50 ml/min. The morphology of catalysts was acquired by field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) using JEOL JSM-7610F instrument. For the textural characterization, the HR-TEM images of the catalysts were recorded on JEM-2100 (JEOL) electron microscope at the operating voltage of 200kV. The X-ray photoelectron spectra of the catalysts were recorded on ULVAC PHI/PHI5000 Versa Probell instrument with monochromatic Al Kα radiation. 2.4 Catalytic activity studies The synthesis of styrene carbonate from styrene and CO2 was performed in a 50 ml stainless steel autoclave equipped with an overhead stirrer. The reactor was furnished with a pressure gauge, thermocouple and furnace, which are all connected to the controller unit to monitor pressure and temperature. Prior to each reaction, the catalyst was preheated in a hot air oven for 1 h at 110 °C. In a typical reaction procedure, 15 mmol of SO (1.8 g), and 12 ml of dimethylformamide (DMF) as a solvent were taken in the reactor. Then, a preheated catalyst (10 wt.% w.r.t. epoxide) was loaded into the reactor. The reactor was flushed with CO2 to eliminate residual air from the reactor and pressurized to the required pressure. Later, the reaction mixture was mechanically stirred at 700 rpm and the reactor was heated to specified temperature. After the reaction, the heating and stirring were stopped and the reactor was cooled in an ice bath. The gas in the reactor was analyzed by Agilent Technology Inc. GC equipped with GS-GasPro column (0.32 mm ID and 30 m length) and Thermal conductivity detector (TCD), then it was vent off by releasing the pressure. The liquid product was centrifuged to separate out the reaction mixture and the catalyst. Then, it was analyzed by Shimadzu GC-2014 AF equipped with DB-WAX column (0.25 mm ID and 30 m length) and flame ionization detector (FID). % C o n v e r s i o n = M o l e s o f s t y r e n e o x i d e c o n v e r t e d I n i t i a l m o l e s o f s t y r e n e o x i d e × 100 % S e l e c t i v i t y = M o l e s o f s t y r e n e c a r b o n a t e f o r m e d M o l e s o f s t y r e n e o x i d e c o n v e r t e d × 100 % Y i e l d = M o l e s o f s t y r e n e c a r b o n a t e f o r m e d I n i t i a l m o l e s o f s t y r e n e o x i d e × 100 2.5 Catalyst regeneration procedure The recyclability of the catalyst was tested under optimized reaction condition using DMF solvent. After each catalytic run, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture and washed thoroughly with acetone several times and collected by centrifugation. The catalyst was dried in oven overnight at 120 °C and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. The same procedure was followed for all the subsequent runs. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Nitrogen sorption studies The specific surface area, pore size and pore volume of the materials obtained by using N2-sorption analysis are shown in Table 1 and the isotherms with BJH plots are depicted in Fig. 1 a-b. Firstly, Pure Sn-Ni (2:1) oxide showed type IV isotherm with H1 hysteresis loop which is typical of mesoporous material with ink-bottle type pore structure [76]. The pore size distribution was evaluated from BJH method showing a broad peak ranging from 4 to 25 nm with mean pore diameter of 13.8 nm. The SBA-15 showed typical type IV isotherm with H1 hysteresis loop according to IUPAC nomenclature, which is characteristic of hexagonal structure and cylindrical channels. The upward deviation at higher p/p0 (> 0.6) is due to the progressive filling of uniform mesopores by the process of capillary condensation of nitrogen within these pores. The BJH method was applied to the desorption branch of the isotherm to evaluate the pore size distribution and total pore volume of all the samples [77]. The specific surface area of SBA-15 was found to be 679.7 m2/g with a narrow pore size distribution with mean pore diameter of 7.4 nm. After alkali treatment with 0.1 M NaOH solution, the surface area of SBA-15 decreased to 347.1 m2/g and there was a noticeable broadening of pore size distribution with mean pore diameter of 10.4 nm. Here, the desilication of SBA-15 by the treatment with alkaline solution partially dissociated the silica wall and thus, the pore size of SBA-15-OH increased by the expansion of mesopore channels [78]. The 15 % of Sn-Ni oxide loading on alkali treated SBA-15-OH-0.1 M further decreased the specific surface area of the support to 247.8 m2/g. This could be attributed to the pore filling of SBA-15-OH-0.1 M by active metal loading, which is confirmed through narrowing of pore diameter from 10.4 to 8.2 nm. Moreover, it can be seen that after metal loading, the H1 hysteresis loop of SBA-15-OH-0.1 M remained unchanged, demonstrating the maintenance of the mesoporous texture of SBA-15. Similar changes were observed in case of 15 % Sn-Ni oxide loaded on SBA-15 support. The effect of alkali treatment (Table S1- entry 1–3), Sn-Ni loading (Table S1-entry 4–10) and variation in metal oxide ratio (Table S1-entry 11–14) on the textural properties of the support material were studied in detail. As the concentration of NaOH solution increased, the specific surface area of SBA-15 support decreased due to the desilication process which dissolves the silicate species from the framework. Further, loading of Sn-Ni oxide on support decreased the specific surface area and pore size due to pore filling of mesoporous channels. 3.1.2 X-ray diffraction The well-defined SAXS patterns of SBA-15, SBA-15-OH, 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH and 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15 are shown in Fig. 2 a. The SAXS pattern of SBA-15 has three well resolved peaks in the 2θ range of 0.8°−1.2° that corresponds to (100), (110) and (200) planes, ascribed to the hexagonal mesoporous structure of SBA-15 with 2D symmetry [75]. Further, alkali treated SBA-15-OH, 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH and 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15 materials showed similar diffraction peaks, which suggests that the ordered 2D hexagonal mesostructure was retained even after alkali treatment and active metal loading on the support. However, the peaks shifted slightly towards lower angles, depicting the increase in the interplanar spacing and this hypothesis is further confirmed by transmission electron microscopic studies. Additionally, the decrease in the intensity of the diffraction peaks were observed, which could be attributed to the decrease in long range order of the mesopore structure after alkali treatment and metal loading. Fig. 2b depicts the wide angle XRD patterns of Sn-Ni oxide, 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15, 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH and SBA-15-OH. The highly ordered SBA-15-OH showed a broad peak at 2θ value of about 22°, ascribed to the amorphous nature of silica. The Sn-Ni oxide catalyst calcined at 600 °C showed the diffraction peaks, which can be indexed as cubic NiO and tetragonal SnO2 phases in the 2θ range of 5°–80° [70]. All the prominent peaks of unsupported Sn-Ni oxide can be observed in the 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15 and 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH catalysts calcined at 500 °C, which confirms that the nature of Sn and Ni oxide phases is retained after loading on the support. 3.1.3 Thermogravimetric analysis The weight loss of the materials was measured using thermogravimetric analysis. Calcined SBA-15 lost 3.4 % of its original weight in the temperature range of 30–100 °C due to the loss of physisorbed moisture (Fig. 3 ) [78]. The negligible weight loss of 1.3 % after 100 °C indicates complete removal of template and thermal stability of the sample till 800 °C. The moisture content for SBA-15-OH measured till 100 °C is around 3.8 % which is similar to that of SBA-15. However, further weight loss of 4.3 % at higher temperature could be attributed to the additional silanol groups generated during desilication process. Upon Sn-Ni oxide loading on the SBA-15-OH support, the first weight loss of 4.7 % in the range of 30 to 100 °C could be attributed to physisorbed moisture. After 100 °C, the weight loss was only 2.4 % (reduced by almost half compared with that of SBA-15-OH) which might indicate that silanol groups present in the support act as anchoring sites for metal oxides. 3.1.4 Electron microscopy studies Scanning electron microscopy images confirms rod like morphology of SBA-15 for all the synthesised catalysts (Fig 4 a–d). This suggests that the morphology of the catalysts is not affected even after alkali treatment and active metal loading. The average particle size of SBA-15 is 950 nm length and 270 nm width. After alkali treatment, average particle size decreased (length-810 nm and width-250 nm) due to the dissolution of silica framework during desilication process. Metal loading on SBA-15-OH also showed same morphology with 880 nm length and 230 nm width. Morphology of 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15 was the same compared to unmodified SBA-15 and the average particle size 750 nm length and 375 nm width. The elemental compositions of catalysts (Si, O, Sn and Ni) were confirmed by EDX spectrum and ICP-OES analysis are summarized in Table S3. Transmission electron microscopy images of all the samples are shown in Fig. 5 a–d. The SBA-15 showed well-ordered and relatively uniform hexagonal arrays of mesoporous channels. The mean pore diameter of SBA-15 is 6.2 nm and the pore wall thickness is 4.2 nm (Table 2 ). After alkali treatment, the pore diameter of the material increased slightly to 6.6 nm due to desilication. This also slightly dissolved the silica wall thereby decreasing the pore wall thickness to 3.9 nm. The leaching of silicon from the SBA-15 framework during the alkaline treatment increased the unit cell parameter from 9.4 to 9.8 (Table 3 ). The ordered hexagonal structure of the material is retained after active metal loading of the support. This observation is well in accordance with the N2-sorption analysis where we found an increase in the pore size of the support after alkaline treatment. From these images and N2-sorption analysis, we can conclude that a large part of Sn-Ni oxide is distributed within the hexagonal pores of the support. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of SBA-15 reveals the amorphous nature of the material and similar pattern was observed for SBA-15-OH. Loading of crystalline Sn-Ni oxide on support materials is reflected by an appearance of weak diffraction rings in the corresponding SAED patterns of samples (Fig. 5c4 and d4). 3.1.5 Temperature programmed desorption The temperature programmed desorption analysis is used to identify the nature, number and strength of the acidic and basic sites in the catalyst. The strength of acidity and basicity viz. weak, medium and strong was recorded at temperatures, <200 °C, 200‒350 °C and >350 °C respectively. Mainly, the weak and medium acidic and basic sites were dominated in all the catalysts reported in Table 3. The acidity of pure Sn-Ni oxide was 144 µmol/g, whereas 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15 showed much higher acidity of 357 µmol/g with only 15 % total metal oxide loading. This enhancement in acidity could be due to the well-dispersed Sn-Ni oxide particles on the support with much lesser agglomeration of particles compared to their unsupported form [79]. The support SBA-15 with surface silanol groups also contributed to the total acidity. The catalyst 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH showed higher acidity of 391 µmol/g compared to 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15 (357 µmol/g) catalyst, where it possesses predominantly stronger acid sites in addition to similar number of weak and moderate acidity, which is due to the increased silanol groups after alkali treatment (Fig. 6 a and Table 3). The pure Sn-Ni oxide exhibited basicity of 119 µmol/g, whereas the 15 % Sn-Ni oxide on SBA-15 and SBA-15-OH both exhibited identical basicity of 97 µmol/g. The results showed that the 15 % Sn-Ni oxide on the support proportionately increased the amount of basicity by 5.4 times compared to unsupported Sn-Ni oxide (Fig. 7 a and Table 3). This could be due to the effective dispersion of active metal oxides on the support which gave more exposure to the surface acid/base sites compared to their bulk form [80]. The TPD profiles (Figs. 6b and 7b) of supported metal oxide showed an additional peak at higher temperature range compared with those of pure Sn-Ni oxide. This can be attributed to active sites generated by SBA-15/SBA-15-OH support, and thus there was an increase in the acidity and basicity value. With increase in the loading of active metal oxides from 5Sn2.5Ni to 10Sn5Ni, acidity and basicity number also increased. However, further increase in the metal loading to 30Sn15Ni decreased the acidity and basicity of the catalyst affecting primarily the weak and moderate acid and base sites, which could be due to agglomeration of metal oxide species. Later, 15 % of metal oxide concentration was kept constant and the ratio was varied (Figs. S1 and S2) as 1:2, 1:1 (Table S2-entry 8-9), and 2:1 (Table 3-entry 4), where these combinations showed total acid-base sites of 382, 541 and 488 µmol/g respectively. The Sn-Ni oxide loaded with 1:1 ratio showed highest active sites value which could be attributed to an efficient dispersion. The 15 % loading of individual oxide on the support exhibited total acid-base sites of 371 µmol/g (15Sn/SBA-15-OH) and 562 µmol/g (15Ni/SBA-15-OH). 3.1.6 Temperature programmed reduction H2-TPR profiles of 15Sn/SBA-15-OH, 15Ni/SBA-15-OH and 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH are shown in Fig. 8 . The TPR plot of 15Ni/SBA-15-OH showed a broad peak 300–700 °C attributed to reduction of different types of NiO species anchored to the support SBA-15-OH in different chemical environments with 1.0 mmol/g of H2 uptake. This metal oxide-silica interaction is associated with the surface-defect sites generated during alkaline treatment. This hypothesis was further confirmed by the XPS analysis. The 15Sn/SBA-15-OH showed TPR plot from 300 to 700 °C with 0.7 mmol/g of H2 uptake. The flat surface from 300 to 620 °C is attributed to reduction of SnO2 species on the support with weak interaction and sharp peak at 620–700 °C is attributed reduction of SnO2 species with strong interaction. In the 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH catalyst both the peaks of pure metal oxide on support are absent and new peak appeared at 370–600 °C, with peak maxima at 520 °C. This appearance of a new peak at intermediate temperature indicates synergic interaction between Sn and Ni and also with the support [81]. The reduction peak of 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15 appeared in the temperature range of 310–550 °C. The shift in the reduction temperature to higher side in case of 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH compared with that of 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15 indicates the better interaction between metal oxide and support [80]. The higher H2 uptake of 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH compared with 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15 shows the better dispersion of metal oxides on the support. 3.1.7 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer The XPS analysis is used for the determination of valence state and chemical composition of the catalysts. The XPS spectra of the catalysts 15Ni/SBA-15-OH, 15Sn/SBA-15-OH, 10Sn5 Ni/SBA-15, 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH are shown in Fig. 9 a–c. The Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 spectra of 15Ni/SBA-15-OH at binding energy 856.0 eV and 873.1 eV, respectively, suggest that the Ni present in the material is in +2 oxidation state. Also, the deconvoluted peaks of Ni 2p3/2 suggest that Ni+2 present in two different chemical environments. The peak at 854.3 eV is NiO and peak at 856.5 eV is assigned to Ni2SiO4 species, signifying the strong interaction between support SBA-15-OH and NiO [82]. As shown in Fig. 8b 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH catalyst shows relative intensity of the deconvoluted peaks of Ni 2p3/2 has increased in the presence of SnO2. This observation indicates that addition of SnO2 has enhanced the dispersion of NiO species on the support. In case of 10Sn5Ni /SBA-15 (Fig. 9c), Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 peaks at binding energy 855.3 eV and 872.7 eV respectively, showing Ni in +2 oxidation state. The broad and asymmetric peak of Ni2p3/2 shows a similar kind of interaction with support, SBA-15. The Sn 3d spectrum of 15Sn/SBA-15-OH, 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15 and 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH are shown in Fig. 10 a–c. The two peaks of Sn3d5/2 and Sn3d3/2 at binding energy 486.9 ± 0.3 eV and 495.0 ± 0.4 eV respectively, are attributed to Sn4+ state which correspond to SnO2 species. The Si 2p spectra (Fig. S3) of the catalysts show peak at binding energy 103.2 ± 0.2 eV is corresponding to Si present in the mesoporous silica framework and the binding energy at 532.6 ± 0.1 eV of O1 s spectra (Fig. S4) are ascribed to the hydroxyl group associated with Si-OH. 3.2 Catalyst activity studies 3.2.1 Screening studies The cycloaddition of CO2 to styrene oxide (SO) yields styrene carbonate (SC) as the major product and styrene glycol (SG) as the side product. Initially, the reaction was carried out without a catalyst, where it gave 1.1 % yield under conditions; 130 °C, 7 bar(a) CO2 pressure, 15 mmol styrene oxide, 12 ml DMF (Table 4 -entry 1). This result motivated to design a suitable catalyst with acid-base properties for activating epoxide and CO2 to enhance the formation of the desirable product. Firstly, Sn-Ni (2:1) oxide catalyst was tested for this reaction under similar reaction conditions as mentioned above with 180 mg catalyst (10 % w.r.t. to styrene oxide), which gave 46.5 % SO conversion and 99.7 % selectivity for SC as shown in Table 4-entry 2. To improve the activity of the bulk Sn-Ni oxide, it was dispersed on the high surface area support which provides more exposure to the active components. Primarily, the two supports namely SBA-15 and SBA-15-OH-0.2 M were tested for this reaction. The SBA-15 showed 13.1 % SO conversion and 7.5 % yield for SC, whereas SBA-15-OH-0.2 M gave 32.5 % SO conversion and 13.9 % yield for SC. The poor activity of the support could be attributed to the lack of appropriate active sites to activate the reactants. Thus, it is considered that the combination of Sn-Ni oxide and support SBA-15 can bring out a better activity. Therefore, Sn and Ni (2:1) in their oxide form were loaded on SBA-15 and alkali treated SBA-15 (SBA-15-OH-0.2 M) by sol-gel method. The active metal oxides loaded on SBA-15 gave 42.7 % SO conversion and 86.4 % selectivity for SC (Table 4-entry 5), whereas SBA-15-OH-0.2 M supported catalysts showed more enhanced conversion of 77.5 % and 54.3 % selectivity for SC (Table 4-entry 6). Clearly, supported Sn-Ni oxide showed significantly better activity than pure Sn-Ni oxide for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxide, where the yield of styrene carbonate enhanced by 16-fold, from 4.2 % to 70 %. Dispersion of active metal species on high surface area SBA-15-OH-0.2 M support and increase in surface hydroxyl groups of the support acting as anchoring sites are responsible in enhancement of the activity. 3.2.2 Effect of alkali treatment and variation of Sn-Ni loading on support Furthermore, the effect of alkali treatment of the SBA-15 support on the conversion and selectivity for the desired product was studied. SBA-15 was treated with different concentrations of NaOH solution (0.05 M, 0.1 M, 0.15 M, and 0.2 M) for desilication to generate more silanol groups and loaded with 20Sn10Ni in their oxide form (Fig. 11 a). The 20Sn10Ni/SBA-15-OH-0.05 M gave 46.5 % SO conversion and 74.6 % selectivity for SC in 4 h reaction time. The conversion and selectivity increased with increase in NaOH concentration to 0.1 M (69.2 % and 87.5 % respectively). The conversion of SO increased further to 77.5 % with increase in the concentration of NaOH solution to 0.2 M, whereas the selectivity for SC decreased to 54.3 %. The stronger alkali treatment >0.1 M resulted in an increase in the side product SG, thus decreasing the selectivity for SC. Hence, SBA-15 treated with 0.1 M NaOH solution is considered as a better support and selected for further screening of catalyst composition. Based on these results, the catalysts are synthesized with different concentrations of active metal oxides keeping the ratio same (2:1). There is an increase in the conversion of SO (51.3 to 84.8 %) with increase in metal oxides concentration from 5Sn2.5Ni to 10Sn5Ni, which can be attributed to the increased acidity of catalysts from 293 to 391 µmol/g. The conversion decreased to 69.2 % and 67.2 % with further increase to 20Sn10Ni and 30Sn15Ni respectively (Fig. 11b). The acidity of the catalysts also decreased from 338 (20Sn10Ni) to 256 µmol/g (30Sn15Ni), where the strength of weak and moderate acid sites decreased drastically resulting in lower conversion. The decrease in the weak basic sites with increased metal oxide concentration (from 5Sn10Ni to 30Sn15Ni) resulted in improved selectivity for SC (80.3 to 88.9 %), whereas the medium and strong basic sites showed a marginal variation. This study shows that 10Sn5Ni is optimum amount of metal loading (15 %) on alkali modified support to get better activity for this reaction. Additionally, the reaction was carried out with Sn-Ni oxide, keeping the catalyst weight same as the amount of Sn-Ni oxide present in 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH-0.1 M and obtained 5.2 % conversion for SO and 81.6 % selectivity for SC (Table 4-entry 3). The lower performance of the Sn-Ni oxide shows the need of support material in enhancing the performance of bulk metal oxides as mentioned previously. Keeping 15 % metal oxide concentration constant, the ratio was changed to 1:2, 1:1, 2:1 and 15 % individual metal oxide was also loaded on support and checked the activity. The loading of individual oxides i.e., NiO and SnO2 on the SBA-15-OH gave lower yield of 11.3 % and 29.3 % respectively which is due to the absence of optimum amount and nature of active sites (Table 5 -entry 5–6). For mixed oxide catalyst 5Sn10Ni/SBA-15-OH with 1:2 ratio, both conversion and selectivity enhanced substantially compared to individual oxide based catalysts (55.7 % SO conversion and 81.7 % selectivity for SC). Using equal amount of Sn and Ni in the catalysts (1:1); 7.5Sn7.5Ni/SBA-15-OH showed lower performance with 32.2 % conversion for SO and 69.7 % selectivity for SC. Thus, the catalyst with Sn:Ni = 2:1 (10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH-0.1 M) which gave 84.8 % conversion and 82.5 % selectivity towards SC was the best catalyst with ideal metal oxide combination. Also, 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15 without alkali treatment gave much lower activity (50.6 % conversion for SO and 66.5 % selectivity for SC) which clearly depicts the support SBA-15-OH with a greater number of silanol group has great influence on metal dispersion which reflected in the activity of the catalyst. 3.2.3 Influence of reaction parameters 3.2.3.1 Catalyst concentration Influence of catalyst wt. % on styrene carbonate synthesis from SO and CO2 was studied by varying the catalyst concentration from 5 to 15 wt. % using 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH-0.1 M catalyst. The results illustrated in Fig. 12 a show that as the catalyst concentration increased from 5 to 12 wt. %, both SO conversion and SC selectivity increased from 80.3 to 86.5 % and 74.7 to 76.9 % respectively. Further increase in the catalyst concentration to 15 wt. % varied the conversion only marginally. This could be due to the product saturation on the catalyst surface above 86 % conversion, where the reaction tends to slow down [83]. As there was only a marginal increase in activity above 10 wt. % catalyst, it was selected for further optimization of reaction parameters. 3.2.3.2 Effect of pressure The pressure of CO2 plays a vital role in cycloaddition reaction with epoxide. The effect of CO2 pressure on SO conversion and selectivity for SC was monitored by increasing the CO2 pressure from 7 to 17.5 bar(a) which in turn increases the CO2: SO mole ratio from 1.2 to 2.9. Fig. 12b shows that an increase in CO2 pressure from 7 bar(a) (CO2: SO=1.2) to 10.5 bar(a) (CO2: SO=1.7) increased the SO conversion and SC selectivity from 84.7 to 86.7 % and 75.2 to 85.9 % respectively. Further increasing the CO2 pressure up to 17.5 bar(a), the SO conversion and SC selectivity decrease by 79.7 and 72.5 % respectively. Increase in the molar ratio increases the availability of CO2 and also the pressure brings the molecules closer to facilitate the reaction in favor of the formation of SC [70]. Decrease in selectivity at higher pressures could be due to blockage of basic sites of the catalyst caused due to adsorption of acidic CO2. The obtained results confirm that at 10.5 bar(a) CO2 pressure catalyst showed high conversion and selectivity. 3.2.3.3 Effect of reaction temperature To understand the effect of reaction temperature, the reaction was carried out for 4 h under 10.5 bar(a) pressure and 10 wt. % catalyst loading. It is observed that as the temperature increased from 110 to 140 °C (Fig. 12c), there was an increase in the conversion of SO from 66.3 to 93.2 % and further increasing the temperature to 150 °C did not influence significantly on the SO conversion. The selectivity for SC also increased from 80.5 to 85.9 % in the temperature range 110 °C to 130 °C, however it decreased to 73.1 % at 150 °C due to increase in the formation of styrene glycol side product. Thus, 130 C is considered as the optimum temperature for this reaction. 3.2.3.4 Time resolved study The effect of reaction time was investigated under optimized conditions using 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH-0.1 M catalyst. There was an almost linear increase in SO conversion from 0 to 92.9 % in 5 h, then there was a marginal increase in the conversion till 8 h reaction time (Fig. 12d). The selectivity towards SC was 86.5 % in the first hour and remained almost same up to 5 h reaction time and later it decreased to 79.7 % which is due to the formation of the side product styrene glycol. 3.2.4 Leaching studies and recyclability The catalyst 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH was subjected for the leaching test to check whether any active species leached out in the reaction medium during the reaction. Initially, the reaction was carried out with a catalyst for 2 h and it showed 59.9 % SO conversion. Later, the catalyst was removed from the reaction mixture and the reaction was continued for 8 h. There was negligible increase in the conversion of SO (62.4 %) at the end of 8 h which confirmed the heterogeneity of the catalyst (Fig. 13 ). One of the essential criteria of the heterogeneous catalyst is retaining its activity upon multiple cycles. The reactions were carried out for 5 h at 130 °C and 10.5 bar(a) CO2 and the results are depicted in Fig. 14 . For the 2nd cycle, the conversion of styrene oxide decreased by 2 % compared to the 1st one. From the 3rd cycle, there was a marginal decrease in the conversion in the range 0.5−2 % and the selectivity for SC remained almost the same (<2 %) throughout the 5 cycles. In addition, the re-used catalyst was characterized to check the integrity of its structural and textural properties. The wide-angle XRD pattern of the spent catalyst showed the presence of all the characteristic peaks of Sn-Ni oxide that were present in the fresh catalyst (Fig. S5a). The TGA profile of spent catalyst showed 9 % of weight loss that corresponds to the loss of adsorbed organic species (Fig. S5b). N2-sorption analysis showed type-IV isotherm with H1-type hysteresis loop and narrow pore size distribution with a little decrease in the surface area and almost the same pore size which indicates that the ordered mesoporous structure of catalyst was retained after a number of recycles of the catalyst which confirms the stability of the catalyst (Fig. S5c-d, Table S4). The acidity and basicity values of the catalyst decreased marginally after these recycles (Fig. S3e-f, Table S4). 3.2.5 Cycloaddition of CO2 to different epoxides Different epoxides were tested for the cycloaddition reaction between CO2 and epoxides to synthesize cyclic carbonate under optimized condition using 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH catalyst (Table 6 ). Styrene oxide and 1, 2-Epoxy-3-phenoxy-propane gave lower yield for corresponding cyclic carbonates (78.3 and 71.2 %) compared to propylene oxide and epichlorohydrin (∼83 %) which could be due to the steric hindrance created by side chain substituent of the aromatic epoxides. Cyclohexene oxide gave lowest yield (24.8 %) as it is characteristically different from other epoxides. The epoxide ring of cyclohexene oxide is fused with the six membered cyclic ring which makes activation of epoxide difficult compared with others. 3.2.6 Plausible mechanism Based on the understanding of active sites of the catalyst and the reaction, a plausible reaction mechanism is proposed for the synthesis of styrene carbonate from styrene oxide and CO2 (Scheme 1 ). The silanol groups in synergy with Sn-Ni oxide serve as anchoring sites for the active centers of SnNi/SBA-15-OH catalyst. The reaction starts with adsorption of CO2 on the basic site (B), while SO coordinates with acidic site (A) present on the catalyst surface. The CO2 adsorbs on the coordinatively unsaturated oxygen anion (basic site) of mixed metal oxide forming carbonate species, while styrene oxide adsorbs on the coordinatively unsaturated metal centers (acidic sites). The weakly acidic, free silanol groups may also activate epoxide ring along with acidic centers of metal oxide. The activated CO2 in the carbonate form attacks epoxide and induces ring opening to form an intermediate. The oxyanion species of the intermediate attacks the carbocation to yield styrene carbonate. 4 Conclusions Supported bimetallic oxide catalyst was designed for CO2 transformation into cyclic carbonate. SnNi/SBA-15-OH is a novel catalyst with no prior report and found that the silanol groups act as anchoring sites for the active metal oxide site for CO2 transformation. The Sn-Ni oxide was loaded on the alkali treated SBA-15 support a sol-gel method using citric acid as a complexing agent. The TPD studies showed that the catalysts contained both acidic and basic sites required for the activation of epoxide and CO2 respectively. Supported Sn-Ni oxide showed better activity than pure Sn-Ni oxide by 16-fold due to the better dispersion of active sites on the support which enhances the accessibility of reactants to the catalytic sites. The metal oxide dispersion and its interaction with support was enhanced substantially with the presence of higher silanol groups in SBA-15-OH compared with untreated SBA-15 support as shown by H2-TPR studies and increased the catalyst performance by 55 %. Different compositions of active metal oxide on the modified support (SBA-15-OH) were studied. Sn-Ni (2:1) with 15 % loading was found to be sufficient to get high activity for the reaction. Under optimised conditions 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH gave 92.9 % styrene oxide conversion and 84.3 % selectivity for styrene carbonate at 140 °C and 10.5 bar(a) pressure in 5 h. Thus, the supported Sn-Ni oxide is the efficient catalyst with better recyclability and versatile catalyst for the synthesis of cyclic carbonate from various epoxide with CO2. coredata.dc:description: The bimetallic oxide dispersed on silanol rich SBA-15-OH was designed for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from epoxides and CO2. The SBA-15-OH was synthesized via desilication and active metals were loaded by sol-gel method. Pure Sn-Ni oxide with a low surface area and lesser activity was modified by dispersing it on a high surface area SBA-15-OH. The different characterization techniques such as XRD, N2-sorption, CO2 and NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, SEM-EDX, TEM and XPS confirmed that the surface silanol group acts as anchoring site for the enhanced metal oxide-support interaction. Supported Sn-Ni oxide exhibited 16-fold better activity than pure Sn-Ni oxide, due to improved dispersion, which enhances the accessibility of reactants to the catalytic sites. Under the optimized reaction conditions 10Sn5Ni/SBA-15-OH gave 92.9 % styrene oxide conversion and 84.3 % selectivity for styrene carbonate. The catalyst is recyclable and the flexibility of the catalyst is tested for different epoxides with CO2.
